item.description:
Attempting to make a second crippling strike against the U.S. Navy, the Japanese formulated a plan to draw the enemy out into a vulnerable position. Turning their attention to the small island of Midway, Yamamoto's primary strategic goal was the elimination of America's carrier forces, which he perceived as the principal threat to the overall Pacific campaign. Armed with less-than-full-strength carriers, Admiral Nagumo sought to destroy the U.S. Navy’s counterparts commanded by Admiral Fletcher. The Battle of Midway begins with Japanese aircraft poised to demolish the airfield on Midway Island. The Japanese carrier fleet has just moved within range to retrieve the aircraft after their attack, presuming the U.S. fleet is nearby. Knowing the Japanese fleets are within attack range, the U.S. has launched aircraft from Midway to deliver a counterstrike while maneuvering its fleet to launch an all-out air assault against the enemy flattops.

OBJECT OF THE GAME
The Battle of Midway is a two-player game with one player controlling the U.S. forces defending Midway Island and the other player controlling the Japanese forces attempting to sink the U.S. fleet and invade the island.

While the U.S. faces grim odds in this battle, they have one major advantage – they have broken the Japanese radio code. They know the location and makeup of the Japanese forces; while the exact location and makeup of the U.S. fleet is unknown to the Japanese. The Japanese must first find the U.S. fleet before they can attack it, while simultaneously protecting their carriers from the inevitable counter-attack by U.S. aircraft.

For the U.S. to achieve a decisive victory they must sink 4 of the 5 Japanese carriers, matching the success of the real battle. Sinking 3 Japanese carriers or any combination of 4 capital ships (carriers and battleships) will give the U.S. a major victory. The Japanese will achieve a major victory if they sink 2 of the 3 U.S. carriers and destroy the airbase at Midway, forcing the remaining U.S. ships to retreat; and a decisive victory if they sink all 3 U.S. carriers and destroy the airbase at Midway, which paves the way to land the troops and take control of the island and the Pacific theatre. Alternatively, each unit in the game has been given a Victory Point value. The game can be played to 10 or 12 Victory Points (recommended), depending on the length of game you want. If both sides achieve the required points in the same turn, the side with more points wins the battle.

In "Quiz Granny o Cywilizacji: czÄ™Å›Ä‡ 2" (Granna's Quiz about Civilization: part 2) players try to answer correctly and reach the place in the middle of the board. The board consist of 6 paths (one for each player). Each path consist of 15 fields/points. If a player answers correctly, he/she rolls the die and move. The players have to stop before barricades, but also have the possibility to move them to stop other players. The first player in the middle of the board is declared the winner.

The surrounding world is changing all the time. New inventions displace old ones. Scientist discover more and more secrets of nature. On movie scenes, workshops and laboratories new work is being done continually. Welcome to fun. Civilization achievments from the Valley of the Kings to the Silicon Valley are just before you.

Let's play! Check your knowledge! Learn new things! Good luck!

Quadrigon is a game of shapes for two or three players. The hexagonal board is marked out as shown in diagram 1. Each player has a sufficiency of coloured triangular shapes of a similar size to those marked on the board. The shapes of each player are of a distinctive colour. The objective is to place these pieces on the board and form quadrilaterals.

In turn, each player places one of his pieces in a triangular space on the board, touching another piece already on the board (excepting of course the first piece laid). They may touch either along adjacent sides or at the points.

Quadrilaterals of many different shapes and sizes can be formed. Some examples are shown in diagram 2. The only quadrilateral which does not count towards a score is one formed by placing two pieces edge to edge (diagram 3). In order for a player to score points for a quadrilateral the following conditions must be satisfied:
1. Exactly half of the counters forming the quadrilateral must be of the colour of the player who has completed it;
2. The perimeter of the quadrilateral must not at any point pass between two counters of the same colour;
3. There must be no empty spaces in the quadrilateral.

When a player completes a legal quadrilateral, he scores one point for each piece within its boundaries regardless of colour. Individual pieces can form part of more than one quadrilateral. The game is completed when all the pieces have been placed on the board.

Inkognito is a simple yet elegant abstract game from Germany. The board contains a 5 x 5 squared grid, with the squares in two of the opposite corners being of a different colour to the rest, and designated as Castles. Each player has a set of five plastic pieces. These are cup-shaped and placed ‘upside down’ on the board. Inside one cup of each set is a marker which identifies the piece as a Spy.

The objectives of the game are to manoeuvre one's Spy into the enemy Castle and to discover the whereabouts of the opposing Spy. The achievement of either of these will cause that player to win the game.

At the start, the players set out their pieces on the five squares immediately in front of their own Castle, remembering which piece is the Spy. During his turn a player may move any one of his pieces in any direction as many squares as he wishes. A piece is not allowed to jump over nor occupy the same square as another piece. Instead of moving, a player may choose to interrogate an enemy piece. This is done by moving one of his pieces to rest orthogonally adjacent to the piece to be questioned, and on the next turn asking if it is the Spy. The other player must identify the piece so questioned. If it is the Spy, then the questioner has won the game; however if it is not, then the asking player loses his piece, and if the asking piece was the Spy, then he also loses the game. The rules do not state that it is illegal to occupy one’s own Castle, but one must assume that it is, in order to avoid stalemate. Also the rules do not make it clear as to what happens when a player has all his pieces blocked and cannot move on his turn.

Bluffing is an important part of the game. It is not mandatory to interrogate a piece, even having moved into position to do so, neither is it obligatory to remain in position to be questioned. One can thus chase an opposing piece around the board only to discover eventually that it was a decoy, and in the meantime the enemy Spy is well positioned to enter one’s own stronghold.

As it is only permissible to enter a Castle orthogonally, it is possible to set up an impregnable defence, by placing a piece on the squares either side of it. This ploy however, will limit the number of pieces that one can move, and unless one employs the Spy as a defender, increases the chances of one’s Spy being exposed.

Other World is a fantasy themed game where each player assumes the role of a medieval character with weapon skill and spell casting skill. 
There are two boards in which each places a pawn; the village and the catacombs. In the village players gain basic weapons (tokens), magical spells (cards), and enchanted weapons (cards). Players may also petition the king for increased abilities or to commission new weapons to be made. They may also serve in the king's army to gain influence, gather raw materials, sell materials at market, visit the healer, or hire the sorcerer to create magical items. All the while a dark prince roams the village causing havoc for the players. There are twelve creatures infesting the catacombs that can be fought for treasure, enchanted items, or victory points depending on the level in which they reside. Players use items to manipulate dice in combat.
Each player must move each turn and two players cannot occupy the same space. The creatures in the catacombs get increasingly difficult as a player moves to lower levels. The winner of the game is player to gain the most victory points. The game is played in 60 to 90 minutes and is for 3 to 5 players 12 years and older.

Kickstarter: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/628734072/other-world-0

item.description:
Four gameboards together in one book with magnetic pawns. All four games have an environmental friendly theme. 
Playing and learning at the same time.

The first game is for 1 or 2 players and the goal is to be the first to complete a family of polluters. The game board is full of what not to do.

The second game is for 1 to 4 players. It is like a game of goose, but the theme is safe our planet and learns us how.

The third game is again for 1 to 4 players and takes the players on vacation. It teaches how to have a good time on holiday and still respect nature.

The last game board is for 1 to 4 players and has endangered species as theme. Players move horizontally and vertically over the board and try to reach the end stone.

name.value: Les Pirates sur un plateau magnétique
De Piraten: Spelen Op Een Magneetbord

item.description:
Four game boards together in one book. All with a pirate theme. With each game you discover more about the pirate life.

The book is magnetique and the pawns are magnets representing pirates. Spin the wheel inside the book and try to be the best pirate!
The first plateau "Galleon Pirate" will get you familiar with the names of all parts of a ship. On the second "A collision" you get to know the regions flagship piracy seventeenth century. The third" At your orders captain!"you discover the daily life of a pirate apprentice under the command of a ship captain very authoritarian. And the fourth "Under the Black Flag" is a board game to continue the life of a pirate.

A book of games! Very practical, very handy that you can take anywhere and particularly on the road!

Four games together in one book with magnetic pawns and a spinning wheel. All games have a princess theme.

Games to learn the different dresses of a princes and their queens through the ages, know "skirts baskets", "closed body", "candlesticks" and many other clothing, discover a masquerade costumes and step into the shoes of Marie Antoinette.

The first plate "The Elegant" will get you familiar with the differences dress of princes and princesses through 6 different epochs. 
The second "Frou Frou" will identify the clothes strewn of 4 different princesses to learn the layers of clothes and shoes at the time of Marie Antoinette. 
The third is "Masquerade" at the court of King Louis XV. It will expose the guests dressed as Columbine, Harlequin, Pierrot. Who will get to the buffet first where her prince awaits.
On the fourth plateau "Long live the queen!" Marie Antoinette is going to marry Louis XVI. Preparations for a royal wedding on a game board.

name.value: Les chevaliers sur un plateau magnétique

item.description:
Four games together in one magnetique book with magnets as pawns and a spinning wheel as die.

You dream of tournaments and attack castles? Play with this book and delve into the world of proud medieval knights! 
In the first game you will discover all about the equipment of the knight who is preparing to battle: the various parts that make up his armor, his weapons, the horse's harness. 
The second game takes you to storm a fortress to rescue his lord and discover the architecture of a castle. 
In the third and fourth game you'll find yourself immersed in the thick of the fight, and to awaken the slumbering knight in you, you must be brave and respect the honor code of chivalry.

name.value: En voyage sur un plateau magnétique

item.description:
Four games together in one book with magnetique pawns and a spinning wheel as die.
Easy to take along on vacation, at home or while driving, to pass the time while you're doing the riveting world tour.

In one game you discover the world and it's different continents.
In another game you learn the various ways of travelling: By car, train, boat and air plane.
The third game is a race. Who will get to the finish first?
And in the last game you discover what it needs to be a true globetrotter.

Similar to Bonjour Simone.
44 card shows dogs in different positions sometimes very similar.
Each turn card is drawn from the deck and players must greet dog, bark, sit up and beg or scratching fleas according to card.

If you're the slowest, make the wrong action etc. You take the card. The winner is the player ending with the fewest cards.

A chess variant that provides a larger board (8x9) and adds another piece to the standard chess set: The Duke.

The Duke can move 1, 2 or 3 spaces in any direction but is unable to capture in any adjacent space but can capture in the subsequent 2 or 3 spaces beyond that. The Duke may also jump over pieces to bypass them.

The Duke starts at the King's side, opposite the Queen.

Object of the game is to be the first to get rid of your cards by dressing Cleon, the chameleon

The game consists 48 cards which can be either a head or body, or tail for 16 different chameleons. Each creature will be 2 colors (unique combination), but each of these colors will be found on other chameleons, in different combinations.

Early in the game, the dealer prepares a single chameleon, with elements of the same color, it raises the center of the table. The cards are then shuffled and the dealer deals eight cards to each participant.

In turn, the active player will try play one of his cards to replace a body part of the chameleon in the middle of the table. 
- this card must be the same body part as the removed card. 
- this card must have a color in common with one of the neighboring cards.

If the active player can't play, he draws one card and passes.

Player who gets rid of his cards first is the winner.

This party game is played over an agreed-upon number of rounds. During each round, an "If" scenario is read aloud; for example, "If you needed to break the ice on a date, what would you say?" Every player except the reader writes a response and gives it to the reader, who chooses one to read to the group. Each player besides the reader then writes down who he thinks wrote that response. The correct guessers get points, and the process is repeated for each response.

Meanwhile, at the beginning of each round, "Butts" are assigned to certain players, who will receive points if they perform those "Butts" correctly throughout the round. An example would be, "Raise your arms in the air whenever you speak."

You can play one on one contests, or organize tournaments with any number of players. Paper figures and field are included to get you started quickly.

item.description:
Spurs and Sprockets is a perfect information, abstract strategy game for two players. Players have eight matching tiles that they take turns placing orthogonally into a 4 X 4 grid, in an attempt to link three or four in a row. There is no board in Spurs and Sprockets so the grid grows organically, based on the placement of tiles.

Spurs and Sprockets comes with sixteen tiles and rules for four different ways of playing, ranging from a simple Tic-Tac-Toe-like game where players gain 8 points for four in a row and 3 points for each set of three in a row, to a game where every placement of a tile may result in an attack and removal of another tile.

item.description:
In Mini Mouth, players race to create words with the letters on display, with the fastest mouth claiming the letters used.

To set up the game, place all the letter tiles face down and shuffle them. One player chooses 2-5 tiles and reveals them, then everyone races to name a word that includes all of the letters revealed. (One caveat: If more than one letter with an asterisk is revealed – those letters being J, Q, X and Z – then players need to use only one of these letters in their word.) The player who first names a word that includes the letters claims all of the letters used. If no one can think of a word or players simultaneously call out an acceptable word, return the letters to the letter pool. The next player clockwise then draws 2-5 tiles and the game continues.

As soon as no tiles remain in the letter pool, the player with the most tiles wins!

A pseudo-psychology game, intending to reveal how much you know about your friends and, in return, what they think of you. This is not how to win the game though. The winner is the player with the most points at the end. You earn points by lying, choosing good moves for your playing piece or by drawing cards (100% luck).

Movement is by the roll of two dice. You have two playing pieces (your 'ego' and your 'id'. At ther start, just the ego is used. But once the hex 'Inferiority Complex' has been passed, you bring your id on to the board. Thereafter, you can move one piece the total of the dice rolled or you can move both your playing pieces by allocating one die to the ego and one die to the id. There are lots of cards, five types and when you land on certain hexes you have to take a card and obey the instructions.

The party game Yackety Smack! features a voice recorder called the Sound Smacker and sixty cards divided into four types: singer, slime, karate kid and "Your Choice".

After the cards are shuffled and dealt, the youngest player records two sounds on the Sound Smacker that match the images on two cards, e.g. "Trolololo" and "Squish". The "Your Choice" card allows for, as the name suggests, a sound of your choice.

After this, the players start flipping over their cards in turns. As soon as two face-up cards correspond to the recorded sounds, the first player to smack the Sound Smacker wins and takes all revealed cards and adds these to his face-down pile. The game ends at the end of a round if one or more players have no cards in hand.

The player who collected the most cards wins!

item.description:
Sharpen your memory and your drawing pencil as you play Cartoon It! Each round, you have 30 seconds to memorize a cartoon character with six specific features shown on the character card; each feature (shape of the head, type of eyes, etc.) occurs in six different ways, which are summarized on the Features Board – but you can't look at this board while memorizing the character!

Once time is up, all players draw their cartoon character from memory using hints from the Features Board. As soon as one player finishes, everyone else has 30 seconds to complete their drawings. Each player passes the drawing and character card to another player, who then scores the drawing. Proper head shape? Check! Tongue not showing? No point for you! The more accurate the drawing, the more points the drawer scores, with an extra point for the player who finished drawing first. (For younger players, you can be more lenient with what counts as an accurate drawing.)

The player with the most points after five rounds wins!

Baseball simulation game that recreates player performance based on simple stats found on everyday baseball cards. Game uses a standard deck of cards for quick play resolution. The player simply flips a card, refers to a specific pitcher stat as dictated by the chart and if the pitcher fails that check goes on to do the same for the batter. The game advertises itself as not one trying to replicate pinpoint statistical accuracy but attempts to make baseball cards come to life.

Ice3 is a game played with ice cubes!

Each player starts with some cards and an ice cube, which is placed on a plastic stand. The cards are placed on the table to create the path on which the ice cubes will progress. Some cards make it possible to attack another player's ice cube – dipping it in a glass of cold water, warming it with your hand, blowing on it, putting a pinch of salt on it, etc. – to make it melt a little. Other cards allow you to defend yourself – well, your ice cube anyway – by preventing an attack. If your ice cube melts completely before the end of the game, you're eliminated.

The first player to bring his cube to the 25th card wins.

item.description:
Each card in the Word Wars deck represents one of two letters. Orient the card one way for one letter, or rotate it 180 degrees to use the other letter. The letters may have different point values.

Each player is dealt ten cards and uses them to make three words. Each player adds up the values of the letters in each word and then ranks his words in order from lowest total to highest total. The lowest total words of all the players are compared, and the player whose word has the greatest total scores. The same is done for the other two words. Play an agreed-upon number of rounds.

42 cards in seven sets of six. The sets are named;
1. Contes
2. Soldats
3. Mythologie
4. Métiers
5. Campagne
6. Brigands
7. Animaux

Players must collect as many sets as they can by asking for cards in one of the sets that they have at least one card in that set in their hand. When all the sets are grouped together, the player with the most wins.

This is a reproduction of a game published by Grimaud around 1848, so the graphics are rather interesting.

From the publisher's website: Players or teams compete to list familiar pairs of words or phrases that fit a category for each round. For example, “salt & pepper” fits the category “Food or Cooking”. Score points for pairs not listed by other players. Score extra points for pairs that rhyme, pairs that use the same word twice, triples (three main words or phrases like "red, white & blue"), or quadruples (four main words or phrases). Play 4-8 rounds in a game.

Players catch fish by moving penguins around the play areas, claiming fish tile they leave at the start of their turn. Pieces must move in a straight line and cannot cross voids, and thus the game board becomes smaller and the options fewer as the game progresses.

This edition has fewer penguins than the original (13 each instead of 16) and adds a shark figure that moves according to a die roll and a six-point compass printed on a board. A player loses a fish whenever one of their penguins encounters the shark.

Players place geometric figures onto the board, but must place such that their new piece touches at least one of their previous pieces, but at corners only. The player who gets the most of his or her pieces placed by the end of the game is the winner.

Though named the same, this is not identical to The Strategy Game (2 player), a similar unauthorized replica but of Blokus Duo i.e. just for two players.

item.description:
Dark Knights is a "press your luck" style dice game that is played with six dice. 3 dice are dark and 3 dice are light. The dark dice represent the lower scoring dice, and the light represent the higher scoring dice. A pen and paper are also needed for keeping score.

Points are scored by matching numbers (or face values) on dice. The point value is determined by the numbers rolled as well as the shade of dice within the combination(s) set aside.

French card game aimed at youngsters to get them interested in food preparation.

Eight recipe cards are placed in the centre of the table. Each player gets six random ingredient cards. In a turn, a player must place one ingredient if he can, to one of the recipe cards. He then replenishes his hand. Play proceeds until one recipe card is completed with all its ingredients. The player who laid the final ingredient claims the recipe card which will be worth a number of points. The more ingredients a recipe needs, the more points it is worth.

When all the recipes are claimed, the player with the most points, wins.

name.value: Legends of the Ancient World: Emerald Twilight

item.description:
This is a programmed paragraph-based adventure game with tactical combat. It is very similar to, and compatible with, Melee and Wizard of Metagaming's The Fantasy Trip. Legends of the Ancient World is the fantasy genre series of these games from Dark City Games. Emerald Twilight is a jungle themed adventure in the series. It is designed to play very well solo, but rules are provided to run it more like an RPG with one or more players cooperating to complete the adventure with another player administering the game as a referee.

Battles are fought with counters on a hex map that is included with the game.

The basic game play of Tsuro of the Seas resembles that of Tom McMurchie's Tsuro: Players each have a ship that they want to sail — that is, keep on the game board — as long as possible. Whoever stays on the board the longest wins the game.

Each turn players add "wake" tiles to the 7×7 game board; each tile has two "wake connections" on each edge, and as the tiles are placed on the board, they create a connected network of paths. If a wake is placed in front of a ship, that ship then sails to the end of the wake. If the ship goes off the board, that player is out of the game.

What's new in Tsuro of the Seas are daikaiju tiles, representing sea monsters and other creatures of the deep. Notably, daikaiju can move: each tile has five arrows, four for moving in each of the cardinal directions and another one for rotation. On the active player's turn, he rolls two six-sided dice; on a sum of 6, 7, or 8, the daikaiju will move, while on any other sum they'll stay in place. To determine which direction the daikaiju tiles move, the player then makes a second roll, this time with a single die. On 1-5 in the second roll, each daikaiju moves according to its matching arrow. On a 6 in the second roll, a new daikaiju tile is added to the board.

If a daikaiju tile hits a wake tile, a ship, or another daikaiju tile, the object hit is removed from the game. Another way to be ousted! The more daikaiju tiles on the game board, the faster players will find themselves trying to breathe water...

name.value: Race of the Turtles and Hares

item.description:
For two players

Object: to get all checkers from one aide of the board in the illustrated squares to the opposite side.

Place 22 red and 22 black checkers on the squares with illustrations on them. Players shake the dice and moves either one or two men diagonally across the board toward the other side. If 1 man is moved add the pips of the dice roll together and move that many squares. If 2 men are moved then move each checker the number of squares showing on each die. Players may jump their own or their opponents men.

Player first reaching the opposite side with all his men wins the game.
Rules from National Games Archives.

Each player has a card that features seven one-word clues. Each clue calls for a one-word answer that will complete a compound word or two-word phrase. For example, the clue may be "Black" and the answer "Jack".

The reader reads the first clue from his card, and the other players shout out as many possible answers as they can think of in ten seconds. The first player to guess the correct answer moves his playing piece three spaces on the board. If no one guesses the correct answer, the reader makes up a sentence to help out the guessers, such as, "Ben likes to visit Vegas to play Black ________." A correct guess now earns both the reader and the guesser two spaces on the board. The next player becomes the reader, and play continues until one player reaches the Finish line.

Tide of Battle is a customizable card game for 2 or 4 players.

Players take on the role of martial artists in combat with each other. Each player has a deck of 30 Tide of Battle cards, each card representing a martial arts technique. These cards are played as attacks or defenses against one another, with successful attacks subtracting from a target player's HP. A player begins with 30 HP and is knocked out, losing the game when that player reaches 0 HP.

The red deck contains five each of the numbers one through ten. The green deck contains 90 consecutive numbers from 11 to 100. Four green cards are randomly placed face-up in a row. Eight red cards are randomly placed face-up ---- four in a row above the row of green cards and four in a row below the row of green cards.

Players simultaneously use the red numbers and up to four mathematical operations to form an equation that equals one of the green numbers. The red cards used in an equation are discarded; the player who formed the equation keeps the green card. The green card is replenished immediately. The red cards are replenished when no player can form an equation with the red cards that remain on the table.

Play continues either until a player's green card values equal an agreed-upon total or until a player acquires an agreed-upon number of green cards.

Think Thrice consists of 25 tiles, each with three attributes: the foreground color (red, yellow, or blue); the background color (green, violet, or orange); and the shape of the picture on the tile (sun, moon, or star).

Each player begins the game with four tiles. On his turn, a player either draws a tile from the bag or plays one or more tiles to the playing area to form one or more triads. A triad is a set of three tiles in which either an attribute is the same on all three tiles or it is different on all three tiles, as in the game of Set.

In making a play, a player may link his tiles to existing ones in the playing area or keep them separate. He also may re-arrange previously played tiles, provided that every tile in the playing area remains part of a triad.

The first player to run out of tiles wins.

Goodfellas is a party game for 4-6 players. A remake and retheme of the basic game and mechanics for Advanced Civilization, Goodfellas pits 1920's era mob bosses against each other. Each player starts with a plan to build their empire, focusing on Italian restaurants, speakeasies, barber shops and other familiar tropes. Starting back in their respective neighbourhoods, players assign their thugs to different locations where they can gather weapons, recruit more thugs, or otherwise build up their organization. In order to complete their empire they will need to go "downtown" where the real goodies are. The problem is downtown is small and everybody is trying to control the same bit of turf in order to get the materials they need. Get ready for the blood to flow!

Using beloved conventions of the mafia genre, Goodfellas will have players picking between tommy guns and piano wire, telling each other to "fuggetaboutit", and ALWAYS taking the cannoli in this fun game intended to make you laugh and strategize at the same time.

Raid sur Bruneval 1942 - Raid on Bruneval 1942 - (Operation Biting) is a solitary tactical game that appeared in the French Vae Victis magazine #104 (special game edition). It simulates the Raid of British paratroopers under Major Frost's command to capture a german radar near Bruneval (northwestern France) during the night of february 27th 1942. During this operation, the british dropped by parachute must capture the radar, one or two german operators, destroy the manor and finally embark all in the waiting Landing Craft Assaults.

The game is edited under ziplock and contains a A3-size map depicting Bruneval surroundings at night (scale at 1/25000), 108 counters (the 3 formation of British paratroopers Drake, Nelson and Rodney ; german coastal defense, luftwaffe guards, MGs, pill-boxes and part of 685th infantry regiment reinforcements ; activation and other markers). One typical counter unit represents around 10 men. The rules are included in a separate 15 pages A5-sized booklet.

The duration of the game is 13 turns from 0:15 et 03:15 am. The player plays the British side first each turn and then the activated german units fight, move and get reinforcements in this respective order. Except for the coastal defenses, the german units are not represented on the map at the beginning. Instead, several randomly selected activation markers are deployed in specific areas of the map. The combination of proximity to British units and alert level may trigger an activation marker that may hide from 0 to 4 german units. These activated units may then fight and move. German move is dictated by closest (in PM) and largest enemy stack or German stack. Combat is resolved by comparing the strength of both adjacent stacks modified by the presence of an officer, the terrain modifier and 1D6. Largest score inflicts one step loss to the other.
The British must score at least 10 victory points to get a marginal victory. More than 20 is a decisive victory. The historical score is 24 VP.

item.description: This is a party game with question cards in five categories (love, sex, life, spirituality and leisure). The active player rolls a color die to determine a category, reads the question on the first card of the corresponding color and answers it. The other players form a jury and award 0-5 points for the answer. The first player to reach a certain number of points (depending on the number of players) is the winner.

SOLAR STARFIRE is the sixth edition of the Starfire series. Starfire has two parts: tactical combat and a strategic campaign system.

The tactical combat is a fast paced, fleet-level starship combat system with both a tactical level and an operational level. The tactical level is where starships engage in ship-to-ship combat around planets and warp points. The operational level is where you maneuver your fleet of starships across a star system to find where your enemy is hiding. Starship designs are simple, easy to create, and the combat system is quick enough to let players destroy dozens of starships in an evening.

The campaign system allows a player to start an empire and control all aspects of expansion: research, construction, colonization, exploration, etc. in an attempt to build an empire. Designed with procedurally generated system generation and a non-player race generation, each campaign is literally unique. The campaign system has been made to be easily modified for custom games and the rules have a hundred additional pages of source materials to help create those custom games.

Originally started as an upgrade of the Ultra Starfire rules, Solar Starfire is based on Ultra Starfire and has become a living work with new goals and purpose. The rules are being built by a new team of developers that have plans to continuously adapt and upgrade the game with new material, new release methods, and most of all - the new storyline. Solar Starfire was built specifically for the history of the Terran Solar Union and will continue to be expanded as the story line opens up new possibilities.

Still using the unique tactical combat system designed in 1976, Solar Starfire is the same core gaming system as Starfire has always been. The new team is building free starter materials for new players to learn and demo the Starfire system, while the website maintains a community forum and a FREE downloads section with player-created materials and previously-available gaming materials for most editions of Starfire.

item.description:
Somewhere on the island is buried a chest full of gold doubloons. The task of the players is to try and locate the exact position of this hidden treasure. It can be achieved by the simple means of elimination.

The map is divided into forty-nine squares which are numbered horizontally and lettered vertically (fig. 1). There are also fourteen 'location cards' each containing a reproduction of the island map and with either one row or one column shaded (fig. 2). At the beginning of the game, these cards are divided into two packs, one containing the numbered columns and the other the lettered rows. Each pack is shuffled and placed face down and the top card drawn from each. These cards remain unseen and give the exact location of the treasure. For example; should the card with column 3 shaded be drawn together with the card having row F shaded, then the position of the treasure is at square 3F. The twelve remaining cards are shuffled together and dealt equally amongst the players of whom there may be two, three or four.

Each player also receives eight digging tokens. Having looked at the cards in his hand, the first player will place one of his tokens on a square on the map board, say B6. If the player on his left has a card indicating either row B or column 6 or indeed both, then he simply says 'No' and the first player's turn ends with the knowledge that possibly the treasure is not buried anywhere in column 6 and/or row B.

Players continue to place tokens in turn until one of the players suggests the location of the treasure chest. That player then looks at the cards selected at the beginning of the game. If correct, that player wins, if not the cards are replaced face down and that player is out of the game.

A variant suggested by the inventor, which makes a longer but possibly a better game, is where each player only has one token and, after it has been placed on the board during the first round, it may only be moved to an orthogonally, adjacent square on each succeeding turn.

Game description from the publisher:

"You can make a profit in several ways – either by producing goods yourself or investing in other players' activities. But which method is more efficient – should you depend mainly on your own wisdom or would you prefer the way of passive investing? Answer can be found from Making Profit: The Boardgame. 2-6 players. Money. Stock. Production. Everything depends on you!"

In Making Profit: The Boardgame every player is both factory manager and investor at the same time. As factory manager you have to decide: should you run the factory for profits or develop it instead... and what area to develop: resource or products? As investor you have to choose the factories to invest into; should you stick close to your own plant or are there more lucrative options made available by opponents? But there are so few actions available each turn...and at the end the winner is the one with most combined wealth.

item.description:
A colour recognition and memory game for children.

Game components: 25 cardboard tiles, 4 wooden pawns, 1 colour die

The game is divided into two parts. In the first part, players create the path towards the bee hive by throwing the die and adding a tile with a flower in the matching colour. Once all the tiles have been added, the second part of the game starts. Players now try to get their wooden bee pawn back to the bee hive. The die now dictates which flower is to be visited next. The active player has to memorise the colour sequence up to that particular flower and has to name it with closed eyes. They get to move their pawn up to the last correctly remembered flower. The player whose bee reaches the hive first wins the game.

A harvest-themed racing game for children.

Components: One board with a spinner, 16 harvest cards, 4 pawns, 2 dice

Aim of the game: Being the first player to collect one's harvest (4 different harvest cards) and get it to the barn.

How it is played: Each player takes a farmer pawn, puts it on the corresponding farm space and places the corresponding harvest cards (potato bag, corn, cabbage and wheat) on the corresponding field. Players then take turns moving the spinner, throwing the die/dice (except during a thunderstorm) and moving their pawn.
The spinner shows the weather: Sun helps the farmer with the harvest - use both dice and move the corresponding number of spaces. Wind also helps the farmer to move faster - throw one die, move, turn the spinner again. Rain slows the farmer down - use only one die. Thunderstorms mean its too dangerous - the player loses one turn.
Pawns are moved from the farm to the field, where one harvest card is taken up and then brought back to the farm. On the players next turn, he moves his farmer to a different field etc.
The game ends when one player's farmer has taken all his harvest cards to his farm.

Simple trivia game with questions on the Soccer World Cup 2002.

Components: board, 55 cards with 6 questions per card, 1 die, 6 pawns

How it is played: The die decides which question (number 1-6) on the current card the active player has to answer. 4 possible answers are provided. If the active player chooses the correct answer, he/she moves his/her pawn one space forward. If the answer is wrong, the pawn is moved one space back. 3 times per game each player may use a joker, which means that the player who reads the question reduces the answer options to two. The player who is first to reach the ninth and final space on the board wins the game.

Each player uses a brain-shaped board that shows twelve categories. Next to each category is a hole in which to place a marble. The three-pronged spinner displays the same twelve categories, as does each card in a deck of trivia cards. Players take turns spinning the spinner and answering the three questions on a card that correspond to the categories that the spinner points to.

The twist is that a player cannot answer any of the questions until all three have been read; meanwhile, the other players spell out a sentence --- one letter per player --- that appears on a card that is turned over after all the questions have been read. Thus, the guesser is trying to remember the answers to three questions, while the other players distract him.

A player places a marble on his brain next to each category for which he correctly answers a question. The first player to fill all twelve holes in his brain wins.

Trivia game "60 years German Federal Republic", covering the years 1949-2009.

Components: 110 cards, 36 betting chips, 4 emergency chips, 6 pawns, one number die, 1 board.

Aim of the game: Being the first to reach the final space on the board.

How it is played: Each player gets a pawn and 6 betting chips. Each round, the active player throws the die, draws a question card and reads the question and possible answers corresponding to the roll of the die. The other players choose one of their betting chips (with values 1-3 on the back) and place it on the answer fields (A, B or C). After the active player has read the correct answer, a player who has put his/her chip on the wrong answer loses that chip. Players who bet on the correct answer move their pawn the number of spaces corresponding the value on the chip they bet. Their chips are returned for further use. Then it is the next players turn to read a question.
If nobody chose the correct answer, the active player gets to move his/her pawn according to the number of players in the game. If a player has lost all their betting chips, he/she gets an emergency chip (value 1). Players can earn back chips if they land on a city space (or they may chose to move 1-3 spaces instead: 1 space if he/she is in the lead, 3 if he/she is currently in last position, 2 spaces in all other cases).
The game ends when a player reaches the final space.

Tóncc is a strategic game for two or three players with Simultaneous Action Selection. 
The board is randomly build up by the 18 Tóncc (disks). Each Tóncc has a unique color/symbol. Each player has a dice, a cylinder and pawn. They secretly decide where to move their pawn and if to acquire the corresponding Tóncc. Goal of the game is to get one or more "three in a line" (colors or simbols) in fewer moves as possible.

item.description:
This dice game required each player in turn to roll the dice in order to determine if your shot cleared the net and either produced a winner or the ability for your opponent to return the shot


The game came with a fame board, 2 wooden dice and 3 wooden pegs used to show present location of the ball.

Each player begins with a set of eight d8s* in the same color. Three gray d8s that belong to no player are rolled first and are not re-rolled for the remainder of the round. Then, the remaining dice are rolled, and each player must freeze at least one of his dice. The non-gray, non-frozen dice are re-rolled, and each player again must freeze at least one more die. The round ends either when all players' dice are frozen or when the dice have been rolled four times.

At the end of the round, a player scores no points unless he has rolled three dice that match the face values on the gray dice. If his dice have matched, then his score is the sum of the face values on his five other dice. Another round begins, and play continues until a player reaches 150 points.


 Note: in the Stones Ultimate version, the game play is the same, but the players’ eight dice are different: two d12, three d8, and three d6. This makes for more interesting game play trying to match the three numbers on the grey d8s.

Children's card game featuring Benjamin Blümchen.

From a hand of cards, each player adds a card to the face-up stack pile. The card added must be either the same colour as the previous card (thus changing the number) or the same number (thus changing the colour. Being a game for youngsters, after they have made a legal play, they can then add any other card from their hand to the stack (so, in one turn, they should be able to use two cards).

The first player to use all their cards, wins.

Children's card game.

Every player gets five cards. A random card starts the discard stack. Each player must try to add a card to the stack. It must either be the same colour or the same number. Next player does the same and so on. If a player cannot make a legal play, he draws a card from the deck and adds it to his hand. The first player to use all their cards, wins.

To spice the game up, any player can play an Action Card to the discard pile in their turn. This causes annoyances such as;
Next player misses a turn;
Next player draws a card from the deck;
You can choose the colour that the next player must play to;
All players jump to their feet and make the sound of the animal currently on top of the discard pile. The first to do so is alright but all the other players must draw a card.
And their are further action cards than these examples.

item.description:
In Zombies at your Heels, 2-4 players each take an identical stack of survivor cards and try to lead them to safety, away from a pursuing horde of ravenous zombies.

Survivor cards are played in a queue that stretches from the Zombie Horde card to the safety of the Bunker card, and each survivor has a special ability - most of which manipulate the order of cards in the queue.

Each survivor card also has as a speed value and a points value. The speed value determines where in the queue the survivor starts when played, and the points value is how many points that survivor is worth if led to safety by the end of the game.

All profits from Zombies at your Heels go to benefit Special Effect, a charity that develops technology and initiatives to help injured and disabled young people to enjoy video games they would not otherwise be able to.

http://www.zombiesatyourheels.com

item.description:
UNITY is a board game for 2 to 3 players, in which each player strives to unite his pieces… at any cost. By sacrificing the right pieces at crucial moments, you can shatter your opponents' groups as they coalesce, or eliminate a pesky splinter group of your own pieces — anything to create unity.

In UNITY, each player’s pieces start dispersed on the board. Your goal is to create a single group of connected pieces of your colour of any size (even just one piece).

UNITY was initially designed for 2 players, with the neutral pieces being just unmovable discs, but was later adapted to accommodate a 3rd player.

The Basic and Deluxe editions have been replaced by the new Unified Edition, that contains:

• A board with 91 hexagonal spaces.
• A supply of rectangular walls.
• 15 ring-shaped pieces of each colour (purple, orange, and green).
• 15 asterisk-shaped pieces of each colour.
• One counter of each colour to show which player is which colour.
• A carrying case

item.description:
Will you follow the path of righteousness and claim Transylvania for the good of the order?

Will you forge your own path and claim Transylvania through trickery and deceit?

Will you let loose your terrible rage to become ruler of a devastated landscape strewn with destruction and chaos?

The choice is yours. Welcome to Transylvania.

Players take turns playing territory cards from their hand. Each territory adds a certain amount of influence to a players domain. Each territory also requires a certain number of different signets to be placed before it is complete and can be added to a players domain. With each turn a new conquest card is revealed which allows all players to place signets on their territories.

To make things interesting, players can also perform other actions on their turn (drawing cards, placing signets, attacking other players, etc ...)

The game is played in rounds, called ages, which favor a particular faction. Each faction only has 5 ages available and once all five faction ages are complete, that faction is eliminated.

The first player to add enough territories to their domain to gain 10 influence wins the game.

Blockers is a two-player variant of Chinese Checkers, as players race to move all their pieces from the starting location across the board to their home spaces (that is, the spaces originally occupied by their opponent).

The game is played corner to corner on a 10x10 board, with 15 spaces of each neutral corner not in play, resulting in a 70 space playing area. Pieces advance by moving to an adjacent space or by jumping an adjacent piece. Multiple jumps are allowed, in any combination of a player's own pieces or their opponent's.

Each player has 10 Runners and 3 Blockers. Runners may only advance forward toward their goal, never backward toward their starting location, while Blockers may move in any direction. Blockers may also jump over a contiguous line of pieces in its own colour. Finally, no piece may jump over a Blocker, not even another Blocker.

Success is determined by stringing "jump ladders" along for multiple pieces, and by judicious placement of the Blocker pieces.

In this card game players try to replace cards in their hand of three cards so that it gets close to the target of 31 points. The twist is that they can't look at their initial three cards unless they are discarded in favour of other, hopefully better, cards.

Pagat.com says:

This game by Gary Woitzik combines the objective of 31 (Scat, Blitz) with a play mechanism similar to "Golf" (the card game). It uses a special 65-card pack which consists of the 52 cards of a standard Anglo-American deck plus 13 cards with special functions reminiscent of those found in UNO and other games: 2 Wild, 2 Reverse, 2 Skip, 5 Take All, 1 Scramble and 1 Swap.

"Virus" is a fun board game where you battle to spread infection around the world. You act like a Virus and you lead a tactical fight. Each player is one Virus and your goal is to defeat other players and conquer the world. 
The game is simple enough that it can be learned and played in a short time, and the battles are different each time you play a new game. This is a game for 2-6 players and co-operative play. Experienced players should be able to finish one game in 40-60 minutes.

Objective

There are 3 ways to win:
1. Termination: defeat all players.
2. Domination: conquer 30 cities.
3. Days of Infection: conquer the most number of cities after certain number of days (turns).

Components

1. A quad-folded map of the world
2. 6 dice (6 different colors)
3. 240 tokens (6 different colors, 40 tokens for each player)
4. The manual in full color with rules and lots of examples of play

Setup

This game can be played in following setups and modes:
1. 2-6 players (each player on his own).
2. 2 vs. 2 or 3 vs. 3 or 2 vs. 2 vs. 2 (co-operative play).
3. One or two experienced players could play against a greater number of rookie players.

Playing the game

The players take turns and all other actions in clockwise order.
Each day have 4 possible Actions:
1. Do nothing: player skips his day.
2. Infect: player on his day places only once a token on free city adjacent to his conquered city.
3. Bonus: player on his day places Bonus tokens on free cities adjacent to his conquered cities.
4. Attack: player attacks adjacent enemy tokens.

This game is a cooperation between tractor company John Deere, toy car company Siku and Schmidt Spiele. 
2-4 very young children drive a toy tractor around a farm. For this, they roll a die which shows different symbols. For a fruit/vegetable symbol, the active player drives to the respective field, flips over one of the chips on that field and checks whether it matches his/her trailer color. If so, he/she can keep it. If not, s/he drives around the farm house. If s/he rolls a farm house symbol, s/he drives to the stables and takes care of a table of his/her choice. This action consists of acting, making animal sounds, etc. The first player to fill his/her trailer is the winner.

from the manufacturer's website

The Back-to-Basics Baseball Printed Game features a 100 card, die-cut, No-Shuffle Fast Action Deck and complete rules. Everything is printed in stunning, full-color.

This is a full-fledged baseball simulation. The game is fast playing and simple to learn, due to our No-Shuffle Fast Action Deck. Every element of the game is determined right on the Fast Action Cards.

Back-to-Basics Baseball features a unique batter-pitcher interface. Just like the real game, the action begins on the mound with the pitcher. Using a modified log-5 methodology the batter and pitcher ratings are combined to arrive at every result. While the ratings may look simplistic on the surface, they nail down each and every player to play on the diamond. 1961 Mickey Mantle will perform exactly as he did in real life. As will role players like 1983 John Wockenfuss.
 Every facet of the game will come to life with amazing accuracy with Back-to-Basics Baseball. Players will hit, pitch, field and steal bases just as they did in real life.

A card game about traveling from San Francisco to Shanghai, China. The cards of the game of Sky Trails are divided into two parts, Map Cards and Route cars. (24 of each). The map comprise 4 sets of 6 cards each, forming an end to end in proper order and from a route of plane travel from San Francisco in the west to Shanghai China in the east. The route cards show 12 important stops along the way with a picture of a point of interest, the flag of the country, a symbol or emblem or a person or two in native dress. There are two alike cards for each of these 12 stops These cards are numbered San Francisco 5, New York 10, Gander 15, Shannon 20 and so on, Each succeeding card stop traveling East increases in value by 5 until Shanghai (value 60) is reached.

How to play: Deal 9 cards to each player and place th reminder of the deck face down on the table Players draw a card from the deck either from the face down pile of the face up discard pile and then discard a card. The object is to lay down the 6 map cards showing a complete route from San Francisco to Shanghai. The first 3 cars of the lay down must be done together. The other 3 can be laid down one at a time if so desired, After getting the 6 map cards down the next objective is to get consecutive route card in hand an play the down 3 cards together saying I am getting off in Rome which means that you laid down Paris, Geneva and Rome cards and then discarded the other card in your hand scoring the total value of the cars, in this case 90 (25 for Paris,30 for Geneva and 35 for Rome, so the further east you travel the more points you will score. Completing a flight before an opponent has laid down his map cards gets you a 100 point bonus. When playing partnerships, you can play on your partners cards until one map of 6 consecutive cards is completed and then either partner can ask “Would you like to get off in Bombay or some other stop depending on cards held to which your partner must answer yes or no, in which case the one asking is bound by the response of his partner. However one partner may simply say we are getting of in Paris and then lay down the required cards. Scorekeeper then records the score at the end of each turn. First team to 500 or 100 wins the game

Game description from the publisher:

In Open Sesame, a.k.a. Ali, players re-enact the story of "Ali Baba & the Forty Thieves" – but as a push-your-luck memory game.

Each round, one player takes the role of Ali while the other players are all thieves. These thieves must repeat, in turn and without error, an ever-growing list of objects – these objects being the treasures that Ali Baba covets and wants to steal. The question for Ali is whether to stop or not before he covets too much and ends up stuck in the cave, with the treasures falling into the hands of the thieves.

Variant rules allow for only two to play Open Sesame.

item.description:
Monster Allergy is a cardgame, where players try to outbid each outher with the cards they have in their hands.

Players take turns choosing some cards of their hand. They play these cards in front of the player at the left of him and says a number and a color. This player can eather accept these cards and play new cards in front of they player that is next to him, with the only restriction that the number must be higher. Or he can say 'YO!'. When a player shouts YO!, you look at the cards, if the player lied and played a number less then the number he called the player loses some points. If a player has zero points he is eliminated from the game.

The surviving player wins the game.

Minigame using the Empire Builder system included in Train Gamers Gazette 2(1). The cards had to be photocopied onto cardstock, and the board had to be photocopied and laminated.

Players start with enough money to build short lengths of track, and by running their trains and delivering loads to various cities acquire more cash to expand their networks. Game had three Major Stations, no Medium Stations, fifteen Minor Stationsn; and six types of Loads (Fuel, Imports, Penguins, Research Equipment, Tourists and Dinosaurs).

Terrain costs are higher than in other games of this system: 2 for "Clear" and 3 for Mountain mileposts due to the snow and ice. Game is to $150 million.

Like all games in this system, game length depends on the number of players, roughly 20 minutes per player.

Ortho is a game intended to sensitize players to correct writing. It aims to do this by making spelling entertaining and the more they play the more they learn.

Each player takes a token. Then each player takes a card that has 25 words that are arranged in 3 columns labeled Beginner, Intermediate and Expert. Each player takes turns reading a word for another player to spell. If the word is spelled correctly the player moves a space on the board. The winner is the player who reaches the finish line first.

Shifty Homepage at the Designer's Site

Shifty is a square board connection game, where the goal is to create a chain of orthogonally and/or diagonally connected stones between two opposite edges of the board.

The unique feature of Shifty is that on your turn you must either place a stone orthogonally adjacent to at least one friendly stone or you must move any friendly stone, by a chess queen's move, to any empty intersection orthogonally adjacent to fewer friendly stones than the intersection it started on.

As a result you must often forego adding a stone to the board, and instead "shoot" a stone already on the board to a strategically key spot. This sharpshooting dynamic is the source of the game's strategic interest.

User summary

A home-made Japanese board game. Players are alchemists, and take turns collecting various resources from different areas of the board; certain more dangerous but more rewarding, and others safe but rather cheap. These are then used to create various objects which gain points. Players can also hire assistants to help out and raise their stats so that materials from more dangerous areas can be collected.

Comes with mounted board, cards, wooden cubes, paper money and dice.

Whoever is skillful enough to flick the bat off into his or her own compartment gets a star. The game ends when a player has 3 stars in his/her compartment and thus wins the game.

The rules contain also special rules for advanced players and for young children.

name.value: The Strategy game for the whole family

item.description:
UNAUTHORIZED PRODUCTION

 
 
 The information that BGG has on this item indicates that The Strategy Game is a non-authorized version of Blokus Duo.

 


In this two-player game, players place geometric figures onto the board, but must place such that their new piece touches at least one of their previous pieces, but at corners only. The player who gets the most of his or her pieces placed by the end of the game is the winner.

Though named the same, this is not identical to The Strategy Game, a similar unauthorized replica but of Blokus i.e. for four players.

Froggammon is based on the game backgammon and is designed for younger players.

The board consists of modular lily tiles. In the middle there is a large central tile connecting four paths of six lily leaves. Each of the paths is closed by a larger starting area where a player places six pieces of his colour.

The aim of the game is to hop through the water lilies and get all of your frogs to you opponents’ lily pads. On one leaf there can be multiple pawns of the same player. Another player can only put his pawn on a leaf when there is only one pawn of an opponent. In that case the pawn of the opponent has to start over from his starting tile.

The game is stored in a handy storage case with a handle.

WyÅ›cigi rydwanów is a racing game based on roll-and-move mechanics on the topic of chariot racing in ancient Rome. The board depicts a stadium with a grid of squares. Players race around it using chariots with different strengths and speeds. Movements are determined by six-, eight- or ten-sided dice. Special tokens are used to modify movements or to harm other players. A chariot can be eliminated if too much damage is done to it.

Space station "Deep Space Nine" has been invaded by "Cardasians", and the mission is take them out. You should go to "OPS" where there are the main controls of the space station with enough attack counters to defeat "Cardasians". There you can drive it and all their systems. The winner become the Space station Commander.

Each player has a pawns and a set of "attack counters" of the same color that start at SA box at external ring. The goal is to move the pawns around the board to the "OPS" at the center of the board.

Movement is controlled by dice. During movement you should get "attack counters" entering at "Cardasian Police" boxes. All players move around the three parts of the same board, so they may capture each others pawns. Captured pawns are returned to start box ("SA"). You can only move in the same direction until you enter in a "P" box (bridge boxes). From external ring, you should use "LR" box (runebounds shuttle boxes) to go to internal ring. Then, in order to go to central laberynth, you should enter at "P1" boxes with the exact number. Whether you fail, your pawn shuold come back by central gallery to "SA" start box, and you should start the attack again!

The winner is the first player to move his pawn to "OPS" box. He shall be shuttle Commander. The second one shall be the Captain and the third one the lieutenant. Both players shall meet a minimum attack counters (4 & 3 ones).

Dark Eon Assassin is an exciting solo science-fiction boardgame, designed to challenge players of all ages as they infiltrate the Tyrant of Acheron’s palace, avoiding the traps and guards he has prepared, in an effort to rid the galaxy of his maniacal atrocities. You will have a range of high technology equipment and weapons to aid you, but the odds are stacked against easy success…

The board forms your inventory and view of the Tyrant's palace, allowing you to quietly stalk its halls and corridors as you track down your prey. While the palace is explored via two decks of cards and will be different in every game, you will be making important choices all the time that will affect your chances of success.

First, you will need to choose which school of assassins you will be trained by; the school of Dark Eon prizes stealth and deception above all else, while the school of Torsten Rex focuses on ranged weapons and one shot-one kill. Finally, the school of Magna Kurr practices ancient Jovian martial arts and can deal punishing blows with almost any part of their bodies.

You will also need to choose from a highly advanced but very limited range of equipment, including Stealth Suits, Ionised Rail Rifles, Psionic Shields, and many others. Finally, you must pit your wits against the defences of the Tyrant's palace, including avoiding or nullifying traps, evading guards, and defeating the mighty Warmaster Battle Engine as you close in on the Tyrant himself!

This game has been created with the objective in mind of entertaining everyone from age 7 to age 99 while they learn or remember everything necessary about road safety. 
In order to do so, we will be placed on a city where we will have to drive following the indications made by the local police, the visual signs, the roadmarkings, and several obstacles upon arriving at our destination.

Think-Guess-Calculate

An exciting game for 2-6 persons over 6 years of age - encourages quick and logical thinking - good mental arithmetic is the winning factor.

First of all a quiz master is chosen. He spreads the card face down on the table and spins the disk. When the disk comes to a halt he calls out the letter visible in the window of the disk. The first player picks a card and reads out the question Printed on it. All the other players must now think quickly, and the first payer to call a word answering the question which begins with the letter shown by the disk is halt way to winning that card.
The quiz master now reads him the mental arithmetic question visible in the second window of the disk. If the player finds the right answer he has won the card. If his answer is wrong the card is returned, lace down, to the table.

e. g. disk shows: M
card question: name of town
answer: Munich
mental arithmetic question: 8 X 9
answer: 72

If the quiz master doubts the correctness of the answer he can remove the red disk and read off the correct answer from the edge of the disk.
If it turns out that tho player was right, the quiz master is 'out' and this player takes over his duties.
Whoever has most cards at the end of the game is the winner and takes over the position of quiz master in the next game.

In the game there are 8 Player Characters that form the Player Character Deck. Each turn 2 random characters are discarded and then the players secretly choose the Player Character they will play in the current turn.

Each Player Character has 2 unique abilities. The first ability may be used on any turn, however the second ability may only be used in Chapters that the Player Character appears in the book.

Secondly, we have the Story Decks which are composed of: Characters, Quotations, and Objects from the book. There are Story Decks for all 12 chapters of the book. Each card may be played for its cost in the Chapter it appears in. Character and Object cards have a Story Point value that adds to a Player's score. Quotation cards are used to complete a Chapter, which is accomplished by playing 3 cards in the appropriate Chapter, but have no Story Point value. Completed Chapters double the points scored while incomplete Chapters score only the card's combined Story Point value.

You may have noticed that I mentioned the cost of playing a card. In Alice: Adventures in Wonderland the currency we use is Tarts. One of the actions a player may take on their turn is taking Tarts. The Tarts are used to play Story cards. Player's must carefully balance the number of Tarts they have in their possession, because at the end of the game any Tarts they have will count against their final score. They lose 1 Story Point for every Tart they did not return to the tray.

The game board we use in the game is called the Storyboard. Alice travels along a pathway from one chapter to the next, spending only a few turns in most chapters. When Alice moves into a new chapter, cards that players may have in their hands from a previous chapter may no longer be played.

Along the perimeter of the Storyboard is a Story Point Tracker. At the end of each Chapter, players score the cards they played (doubled if they played 3 cards) and all cards from the Chapter (in their hands, played in front of them, or remaining in the chapter's Story Deck) are removed from the game. There is also a Tart Tracker that represents the current number of Tarts each player has in their possession.

In the game, Alice is not a Player Character. She is not even a character in the Story Deck. In the game she is represented by a token that moves along a pathway through each chapter. She is a basically a timer. When the Alice token reaches the final space, the game is over.

Orion is a two player game in which the players first alternately place their spaceships on the intersections and when all ships have been placed, they move them along the grid lines. 
One ship is moved at a time by a player. A spaceship can move from one end of an intersection to the next one, with the exception of the main spaceship (white for one player and black for the other) that can move two spaces.
Spaceships cannot jump over each other. If a spaceship is surrounded by others (enemy or own) in a way that it cannot move (no more free spaces next to it), then it is taken off the board. If more than one spaceship gets surrounded, all of them are taken off simultaneously. If the main spaceship is taken off, or there are only 2 spaceships left from the fleet, the player looses.

item.description:
Unlucky Sevens is an extremely simple and portable game Vegas-style dice game that can be played in a very short amount of time, or over a series of rounds for a longer experience. It can be played stand-alone or as a betting or challenge game for points, rewards, or even drinks. It is simple enough for kids, but with the utility to entertain adults as well.

Players take turns rolling a pair of dice, after each roll taking a Point card corresponding to the roll made. (Even if another player has that card).

When each one of the cards finally belongs to a player, the game ends immediately and players total up their score. But beware, the 7 is Unlucky, and whoever is stuck with it will suffer a negative point penalty!

Paris, XVIIth century. Cardinal Richelieu is centralizing power in the name of King Louis XIII and defends France against those he considers its enemies: the English, the protestants, the Habsburgs and French nobles scheming against him and the crown. Will you side with the cardinal, or will you be seduced by the promise of wealth and power from the queen and foreign nations? Be warned that the cardinal will hinder too ambitious intrigants. Become an influent noble in the court by accumulating prestige and favors. The player most helpful to each faction is also rewarded at the end of the game.

Richelieu is a tactical game with a lot of bluff and interaction, with intrigue everywhere. Every instance of intrigue will pit Cardinal Richelieu against his enemies. The players are nobles taking sides in these intrigues by placing agents with secret values and thus influencing the intrigues. Will you choose to side with Richelieu or the conspirators – or perhaps even help both? You can keep your support secret or make it directly known to others when placing your agents at the intrigues. It costs money to place agents, but the winning faction gives higher rewards for the players that helped them the most.

The Cardinal's mood is influenced by his success or failures, and he will become intolerant against too influential nobles (i.e. the players), who will have one fewer action to spend during a turn as a result.

There are many possibilities and opportunities to score points for the player who foresees and thwarts the plans of other players. During the game, you will constantly have to choose your side: Will you side with the Cardinal, or will you be seduced by the promise of wealth and power from the Queen and from foreign nations?

Winner of Plateau d'or 2009!

item.description:
34 cards, all featuring some of children's favourite characters. The cards are nice and large, just right for little hands. Children's card game that links dominoes with cards.

Each player starts with 4 cards and the first player to the left with a 'Doppel' (i.e. with two pictures the same on it) plays it to the table. The next player must add one at either end, domino fashion, or pass and draw a card from the stack.

The first player to use all their cards, wins.

name.value: Oppida: Cities of the Roman Empire

item.description:
Two thousand years ago, the Roman Empire ruled the lands around the Mediterranean Sea. With peace at the borders, harmony inside the provinces, uniform law, and a common currency, the economy thrived and gave rise to mighty Roman dynasties as they expanded throughout the numerous cities. Guide one of these dynasties and send colonists to the remote realms of the Empire; develop your trade network; and appease the ancient gods for their favor — all to gain the chance to emerge victorious!

Concordia is a peaceful strategy game of economic development in Roman times for 2-5 players aged 13 and up. Instead of looking to the luck of dice or cards, players must rely on their strategic abilities. Be sure to watch your rivals to determine which goals they are pursuing and where you can outpace them! In the game, colonists are sent out from Rome to settle down in cities that produce bricks, food, tools, wine, and cloth. Each player starts with an identical set of playing cards and acquires more cards during the game. These cards serve two purposes:


 They allow a player to choose actions during the game.
 They are worth victory points (VPs) at the end of the game. 


Concordia is a strategy game that requires advance planning and consideration of your opponent's moves. Every game is different, not only because of the sequence of new cards on sale but also due to the modular layout of cities. (One side of the game board shows the entire Roman Empire with 30 cities for 3-5 players, while the other shows Roman Italy with 25 cities for 2-4 players.) When all cards have been sold or after the first player builds his 15th house, the game ends. The player with the most VPs from the gods (Jupiter, Saturnus, Mercurius, Minerva, Vesta, etc.) wins the game.

item.description:
Life is a game! So rings the Odynaut motto. To survive, in other words, the Odynauts must keep winning! And now, they have descended on our planet looking for new games wherever they can find them. On a seemingly innocent and charming little farm, the Odynauts are witness to a high stakes strategic game in which hens are the coveted prize. The roosters seek to draw as many of them in as possible with their charms. A sly fox is sneaking around the coop for a delicious meal, while the farmer is on a mission to catch him in order to protect his precious little hens. The Odynauts, of course, see a highly entertaining game in all of this. Are you the biggest, baddest rooster? Or are you just the smartest one?

Rule the Roost (a.k.a. Hennen Jennen) is a funny and nerve-racking farm-themed card game for two to four witty players of all ages. The goal is to become the leader Rooster of one or more barns and to collect as many chickens as possible for points.

Throughout the game each player tries to obtain a majority in one or more of the three barns with her own rooster cards by placing these cards under the barn cards. For each barn in which a player has the majority of roosters at the end of the game, she receives one point for each of the chicken cards present. Players should try to have as many chickens as possible in the barns in which she dominates by either placing her own chicken cards there, or by banking on others doing so.

But beware! Danger is lurking. Players can prevent an opponent from having the majority of roosters in a barn or collecting chickens in a barn by throwing eggs, playing fox cards or famer cards because foxes have chickens on the menu and the farmer is eager to move roosters from one barn to another.

item.description:
Part 1: The Valkyrie's Spear

An adventure game where players take on the role of a stranded, lady pirate on Terror Island. Cooperatively, players traverse the island, facing hazards and hunters, until the final showdown, where they will battle a villainous dog and recapture their ship.

The game is card and dice driven. It features 12 different pirates, each with a skill and a knack to differentiate them. Players will have to conserve resources, use their skills and make the right team-based choices to survive this challenging game.

Play it solitaire or with up to 6 players.

GAME-PLAY SYNOPSIS

Each pirate begins with 10 points of fortitude and one item given to them at random. With each new turn, the players (the crew) decide together if they will rest or traverse their current location.

If the crew rests, they may perform skills, such as searching for items, foraging for rations or simply resting and recovering lost fortitude.

If the crew traverses, they must each spend fortitude points to do so and then draw cards from the island deck until they reveal a new location card, at which tine the turn ends.

While drawing cards, the crew will encounter hazards from lava bursts to mischievous monkeys and possibly even pirate hunters. When hunters are encountered, the crew will do battle. Battle is a series of dice rolls used to do damage and deplete each side of its fortitude.

The goal is to reach the end of the progress track (crossing the island) and hold a final showdown with the villainous dog who stole you ship and left you stranded on Terror Island.

item.description:
For a long, long time, goblins and fairies have lived in a magical world right beneath our noses. If you look hard enough, you can find rings of mushrooms, called "fairy rings", which act as doors between their world and ours. Today, a gang of mischievous goblins escaped from the fairy ring, and it is up to the players to send them back before they cause trouble! But an ancient spell of rhymes which transforms goblins into fairies and fairies into goblins makes this a trickier task than you might think...

Goblins Drool, Fairies Rule!, a card game of rhyme and reason for kids of all ages, is for 2 to 4 players, and has special solitaire rules for a single player. The game takes about 15 minutes to setup and play. The components consist of 20 unique cards, each card having one side representing a Goblin, and another side representing a Fairy. Each side of a card has one of four Symbols: a Sun, a Moon, a Mushroom, or a Frog. The names of the Fairies and Goblins are divided into five rhyming groups, each name ending in one of five sounds.

Players begin the game with 4 cards each, goblin-side-up. Four cards are placed fairy-side-up in the middle of the table, called the "Fairy Ring". The goal of the game is to be the first player to get rid of all their Goblins by sending them to the Fairy Ring, or be the first to obtain six Fairies. Players take turns adding one of their cards to the Fairy Ring. When a card is added, any other cards in the Fairy Ring which rhyme with the name on the added card are flipped over: Fairies become Goblins and Goblins become Fairies. Once all rhyming cards have been flipped over, the player then takes any cards from the Fairy Ring which match the symbol on the added card. The first player to end their turn with no more Goblins or with six Fairies wins.
